oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery Interviews the Oak Ridge Boys - Parts 1, 2 and 3
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording is from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of the Oak Ridge Boys (performance group) for the Ralph Emery Show. Tape labeled parts 1, 2 and 3. Recording is from June 27, 1984.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Oak Ridge Boys
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Ralph Emery asks the members of the Oak Ridge Boys to introduce themselves away from the microphone -- (00:18) The Oak Ridge Boys radio spot for the Ralph Emery Show -- (00:45) Emery introduces the Oak Ridge Boys, and each discuss how they had renovated their recording studio -- (02:34) Elvira [excerpt] (Oak Ridge Boys) -- (03:09) Duane Allen recalls a story about being picked out of a crowd and being asked to sing -- (04:54) Emery invites Allen to discuss the gospel influences of "Everyday;" additionally, Emery and the Oak Ridge Boys praise Dave Loggins -- (07:46) Allen praises Janie Fricke's vocals while introducing "If the Fall Don't Get Cha" -- (08:15) The Oak Ridge Boys are invited to discuss Merle Haggard while introducing "Let's Chase Each Other Around the Room" -- (09:17) Emery commercial spot for Red Man Chewing Tobacco -- (09:35) Emery discusses the Kimberly Springs group and each individuals background -- (11:07) Emery commercial spot for Red Man Chewing Tobacco -- (11:25) Emery and the Oak Ridge Boys discuss where Hendersonville, Tennessee is, and how fans believe they have stake in a film store -- (13:52) Emery invites William Lee to introduce "It Never Hurts to Hurt Sometime," and the Oak Ridge Boys and Emery discuss their impressions of Randy VanWarmer -- (15:23) Emery invites Richard Sterban to introduce "Shot in the Dark" -- (15:44) Emery recalls a story about a gentleman being intimidated from a pair of disc jockeys -- (16:14) Emery invites Allen to speak praise of the Whites while introducing "Forever You" -- (16:54) Lee jokes about Sonny Throckmorton being a staple in his life while introducing "Trying to Love Two Women" -- (17:42) Emery and the Oak Ridge Boys say their goodbyes -- (18:04) Emery talks with the Oak Ridge Boys off script about the difference of feeling from the album from what was perceived -- (18:50) Emery and the Oak Ridge Boys say hello to each other -- (19:24) Emery invites Joe Bonsall to introduce Dolly Parton, and Bonsall relives his experience from being able to go to the premier of Rhinestone -- (20:03) Emery and the Oak Ridge Boys discuss Bonsall's obsession of movies and Indiana Jones -- (22:42) Emery reflects on what he believed to be the structure of "Ozark Mountain Jubilee" -- (25:07) Emery and the Oak Ridge Boys discuss the difficulties of copyright laws -- (27:15) Emery discusses Johnny Cash's 'tongue in cheek' nature -- (28:16) Emery recaps "Love Song" and asks Allen for his comments -- (29:27) Emery inquires about how Lee had a different name then what he was referred to, and Lee's outdoor event -- (34:32) Emery introduces Conway Twitty's "It's Only Make Believe" -- (34:51) "Cryin' Again" is told by Allen to be a song he immediately believed he should sing -- (35:43) Emery K-Mart and Red Man Chewing Tobacco commercial spots -- (36:01) Emery talks to his engineer and the Oak Ridge Boys about the availability of tape -- (36:36) Emery introduces the Oak Ridge Boys and all of them joke about Larry Gatlin -- (37:50) "Y'all Come Back Saloon" is described by Bonsall as the most important record for the Oak Ridge Boys -- (42:36) Bonsall praises Reba McEntire while introducing "He Broke Your Memory Last Night" -- (43:00) Richard Sterban talks about the follow-up to a band's first hit and introduces "You're the One" -- (44:39) Emery commercial spot for Red Man Chewing Tobacco -- (45:49) Emery and the Oak Ridge Boys reflect on the time where the Oak Ridge Boys were struggling for income -- (51:08) The Oak Ridge Boys recall singing with George Jones and seeing him at a restaurant -- (52:39) Emery inquires about the successes brought on by "American Made" -- (53:22) Emery says goodbye and performs his outro commercials -- (53:44) Emery and the Oak Ridge Boys joke about an attitude adjustment
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Emery, Ralph; Oak Ridge Boys;
